sub_topic: Calculation of the ionization energy of atoms
message_1: Calculate the ionization energy of a hydrogen atom when its electron moves from n=1 to n=∞.
message_2:
The ionization energy of a hydrogen atom is the energy required to remove an electron from the atom. In this case, we are asked to find the energy required to remove an electron from the ground state (n=1) to the point where the electron is no longer bound to the atom (n=∞).

The ionization energy can be calculated using the Rydberg formula for the energy levels of a hydrogen atom:

E = -13.6 eV * (1/n^2)

Where E is the energy of the electron at a given energy level n, and 13.6 eV is the Rydberg constant for hydrogen.

For the ground state (n=1), the energy is:

E1 = -13.6 eV * (1/1^2) = -13.6 eV

For the case when the electron is no longer bound to the atom (n=∞), the energy is:

E∞ = -13.6 eV * (1/∞^2) = 0 eV

The ionization energy is the difference between these two energy levels:

Ionization energy = E∞ - E1 = 0 eV - (-13.6 eV) = 13.6 eV

So, the ionization energy of a hydrogen atom when its electron moves from n=1 to n=∞ is 13.6 eV.
